summary: the interferon (IFN) system is an integral part of innate immunity (1, 2). sensors of the IFN system recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns and induce signaling cascades which induce the production and release of IFN. tetherin's antiviral activity was identified in the context of HIV-1 infection. influenza viruses cause annual epidemics (seasonal FLUAV) and intermittent pandemics (pandemic FLUAV) which are associated with substantial morbidity and mortality (15). the role of tetherin in FLUAV infection has not been well defined. initial studies indicated that FLUAV is only inefficiently inhibited by tetherin or is completely tetherin insensitive (17–19) HEK 293T cells were maintained in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 at 37°C. plasmid encoding tetherin or empty control plasmid 293T cells were seeded in 6-well plates at a density of 2.8 105 cells/well. after 24 h, the cells were transfected with either a constant amount (6 g) or increasing amounts (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0, or 6.0 g) of tetherin expression plasmid, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) encoding plasmid. cells were seeded in 12-well plates at a density of 1.4 105 cells/well. cells were transduced with a murine leukemia virus vector encoding human tetherin. after 24 h, the cells were transfected with 1 g of small interfering RNA specific for tetherin or with scrambled, nonsense siRNA as a control. cells were gently washed with prewarmed DPBS with Ca2+, Mg2+, and 0.2% BSA. after 1 h of incubation, the medium containing viruses was removed. the virus titers in the culture supernatant were determined at 24 h postinfection. 293T cells were transfected with 2 g of plasmid encoding tetherin or with empty plasmid as a control. at 24 h postinfection, the cells were harvested for Western blot analysis. Western blot images were analyzed with ImageJ software to quantify tetherin expression. RESULTS Tetherin inhibits release of neuraminidase-based virus-like particles. the glycoproteins of several viruses were identified as tetherin antagonists (24–29) release of both 1918 NA- and WSN NA-based VLPs was markedly reduced upon tetherin expression. this effect was rescued upon coexpression of HIV-1 Vpu. the results indicate that release of 1918 NA- and WSN NA-based VLPs is readily detectable. the hemagglutinin of the pandemic 1918 influenza virus antagonizes tetherin. we then analyzed whether the 1918 HA and WSN HA proteins can rescue VLP release driven by their cognate NAs from inhibition by tetherin. the tetherin-mediated release inhibition of 1918 NA-based VLPs was rescued by expression of both Vpu and 1918 HA. the results were confirmed in at least five (A) and three (B) separate experiments. the signal intensities measured for panels A and B were quantified using ImageJ software. tetherin-transfected 293T cells, removed input virus by washing. release of the laboratory-adapted virus was markedly inhibited by tetherin. inhibition efficiency correlated with the amount of tetherin expression. similar effects were not observed for the pandemic virus. sensitivity to inhibition by tetherin is strain dependent. 293T cells transfected with angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) plasmids were transfected. the cells were infected with A/PR/8/1934 (H1N1) or A/Hamburg/4/2009 (H1N1). at 1 h postinfection, the input viruses were removed by washing. at 24 h postinfection, the supernatants were harvested and titers determined using the focus formation assay. the results of a single experiment performed with triplicate samples are shown and were confirmed in a separate experiment. wt PR8 and reassortant PR8 viruses equipped with HA and NA of 2009 (PR8 2009 HA/NA) (D) or A/Aichi/2/1968 (H3N2) confer tetherin resistance to pandemic viruses. the HA and NA proteins from several pandemic FLUAV can protect these viruses from inhibition by tetherin, at least in transfected 293T cells. the knockdown of tetherin expression markedly augmented release of A/PR/8/1934 but not A/Hamburg/4/2009. the knockdown of tetherin expression markedly augmented either pandemic FLUAV (A/Hamburg/4/2009 [H1N1]) or laboratory-adapted FLUAV (A/PR/8/1934 [H1N1]), followed by quantification of viral release via focus formation assay. notably, release of the seasonal FLUAV A/Panama/2007/1999 (H3N2) (abbreviated PAN), or pandemic FLUAV 2009 at an MOI of 0.1 (PR8), cells were processed and viral titers determined as described for panel A. results of a HA, or 1918 NA. expression of tetherin and -actin in cell lysates was determined. similar results were obtained in at least three separate experiments. bands with molecular masses expected for NP and M1 proteins are marked with black-filled (NP) and gray-filled (M1) triangles. tetherin antagonists reduce tetherin expression levels in infected cells. reassortant virus equipped with HA and NA of 2009 (PR8 2009 HA/NA) or A/Aichi/2/1968 (H3N2) (PR8 1968 HA/NA) at an MOI of 0.1 at 1 h postinfection, the virus-containing medium was replaced by fresh culture medium. cells were lysed and expression of tetherin and -actin in cell lysates determined by Western blotting. studies employing FLUAV VLP systems provided evidence that release of FLUAV-like particles can be restricted by tetherin (18, 23), although some viral NAs counteract tetherin with modest efficiency (20, 21, 23), potentially by altering tetherin glycosylation (21) both 1918 NA and WSN NA can drive VLP budding, although with differential efficiency. the analysis of reassortant viruses showed that the introduction of the HA and NA segments of a pandemic virus was sufficient to confer tetherin resistance to an otherwise susceptible virus. this finding is not in conflict with most previous studies documenting FLUAV inhibition by tetherin, which exclusively examined seasonal or laboratory-adapted FLUAV (17–19, 21) many viral tetherin antagonists remove tetherin from the site of viral budding, the plasma membrane. for instance, the HIV-1 Vpu protein degrades tetherin and additionally interferes with tetherin transport to the cell surface (6, 7, 12–14) the Ebola virus glycoprotein counteracts tetherin without interfering with tetherin expression or cellular localization. tetherin-resistant and -susceptible viruses differ in the amounts of HA and NA copies incorporated into viral particles. virion incorporation of HA and NA may contribute to tetherin inhibition. tetherin-resistant and -susceptible viruses differ in the amounts of HA and NA copies incorporated into viral particles. tetherin-antagonizing activity of HA/NA is FLUAV specific. intuitive but might be the result of adaptation of HA to immune pressure.
